transcript:
Patient: Reaching out to my friend was really difficult at first. I felt anxious and worried that they would reject me or think I was being too needy. But I remembered what we talked about in our last session, about being specific and direct, and choosing the right person. So I decided to text my friend and ask if we could talk on the phone for a bit, because I was feeling down and could use some support.

Therapist: That's great that you were able to push through the initial anxiety and reach out to your friend. How did the conversation go once you were on the phone together?

Patient: It actually went really well. My friend was really understanding and supportive. They listened to me talk about what was going on, and they shared some of their own experiences with depression and feeling unworthy. It felt good to know that I'm not alone in this, and that my friend cares about me and wants to support me.

Therapist: That's wonderful to hear. It sounds like reaching out to your friend provided some evidence against your core belief that you're not worthy of love and connection. How did it feel to have that experience of being supported and understood by your friend?

Patient: It felt really good. It was like a weight was lifted off my shoulders. I felt less alone and more connected to my friend. It made me question whether my core belief is really true, or if it's just a story I've been telling myself.

Therapist: That's a great insight. Questioning our core beliefs and looking for evidence that contradicts them is an important part of the therapeutic process. I'm curious, what was it like to practice the thought records and reframing techniques over the past week?

Patient: It was challenging at times, but also really helpful. I noticed that I have a lot of automatic negative thoughts throughout the day, and that they often stem from this core belief that I'm not worthy of love and connection. Using the thought records helped me to slow down and examine those thoughts more objectively, and to look for evidence that might contradict them.

Therapist: Can you give me an example of a thought that you reframed using the thought record?

Patient: Sure. One day at work, I made a small mistake on a project and my boss pointed it out. My automatic thought was "I'm such a screw-up, I don't deserve to be here." But when I examined that thought more closely, I realized that it wasn't really true. Everyone makes mistakes sometimes, and one small mistake doesn't mean I'm a screw-up or that I don't deserve to be here. I was able to reframe the thought as "I made a mistake, but that's okay. I'm still a valuable employee and I belong here."

Therapist: That's a great example of reframing. You were able to challenge the automatic negative thought and come up with a more balanced and realistic perspective. How did that feel?

Patient: It felt empowering. Like I have more control over my thoughts and emotions than I realized. It's still a work in progress, but I feel like I'm making good progress.

Therapist: I'm really glad to hear that. You're doing great work, and it's paying off. As we continue to explore this core belief that you're not worthy of love and connection, I'd like to introduce a new technique called the Positive Data Log. The idea behind this technique is to actively look for and record evidence that contradicts your core belief. So anytime you have an experience that suggests you are worthy of love and connection, you would write it down in your Positive Data Log. Over time, this can help to build up a body of evidence against the core belief, and make it easier to challenge it when it comes up. What do you think about that?

Patient: I like that idea. It reminds me of something we talked about in an earlier session, about how our brains are wired to pay more attention to negative experiences than positive ones. I can see how actively looking for and recording positive experiences could help to balance that out.

Therapist: Exactly. Our brains are wired to pay more attention to negative experiences because they're often more important for survival. But that can lead to a skewed perception of reality, where we focus on the negative and discount the positive. The Positive Data Log is a way to counteract that bias and build up a more balanced and accurate view of ourselves and the world around us. Would you be willing to try keeping a Positive Data Log over the next week, in addition to continuing with the thought records and reframing?

Patient: Yes, I'm definitely willing to try that. I think it could be really helpful.

Therapist: Great. Let's talk a bit more about how to actually do the Positive Data Log. One way to approach it is to set aside a specific time each day, maybe before bed, to reflect on your experiences from the day and look for any evidence that contradicts your core belief. It could be something as small as a kind word from a coworker, or a moment of connection with a friend or family member. The key is to write it down, no matter how small it seems. Over time, those small pieces of evidence can add up to a powerful challenge to the core belief.
